Its funny, because since it is already graphed on a graph, you can tell visually if it passes the "vertical line test" and the "horizontal line test" because it has both of those things already, at x=0 and y=0, if one of those lines maps to two points, you can predict the outcome of the "tests" because anywhere else you draw those lines would just be x=0+1 and y=0+1 or +5 or +100, etcetera.
